    Trenton Franz

    Assistant Professor

    • Lincoln, Nebraska
    • Website

    Trenton finished his PhD in 2011. After a postdoc at the University of Arizona, he is now an assistant professor of hydrogeophysics at the School of Natural Resources at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

    Trenton Franz's Recent News

    Article accepted in Water Resources Research

    Article to be published in Ecohydrology

    Article accepted in Water Resources Research

    Article published in Vadose Zone Journal

    Quantifying transient soil moisture dynamics using multi-point direct-current resistivity in homogeneous sand

    Article accepted in Vadose Zone Journal

    WAVES Lab Publications by Trenton Franz

    An ecohydrological approach to predicting hillslope-scale vegetation patterns in dryland ecosystems

    *Franz, T.E., Caylor, K.K., *King, E.G., Nordbotten, J., Celia, M.A., Rodriguez-Iturbe, I, (2012) “An ecohydrological approach to predicting hillslope-scale vegetation patterns in dryland ecosystems”, Water Resources Research, doi:10.1029/ 2011WR010524.

    Characterizing ecohydrological and biogeochemical connectivity across multiple scales: a new conceptual framework

    *Wang, L., Zou, C., *O’Donnell, F., *Good, S.P., *Franz, T., Miller, G.R., Caylor, K.K., Cable, J.M., Bond, B. (2012) “Characterizing ecohydrological and biogeochemical connectivity across multiple scales: a new conceptual framework,” Ecohydrology, doi:10.1002/ eco.1187.

    Quantifying transient soil moisture dynamics using multi-point direct-current resistivity in homogeneous sand

    *Franz, T., Nolan, J., Nordbotten, J., Caylor, K.K., Slayter, L. (2011) “Quantifying transient soil moisture dynamics using multi-point direct-current resistivity in homogeneous sand,” Vadose Zone Journal, vol. 10, doi:10.2136/ vzj2010.0031.

    An ecohydrological approach to predicting regional species distribution patterns in dryland ecosystems

    ∗Franz, T., Caylor, K.K., Rodriguez-Iturbe, I., Celia, M. (2010) “An ecohydrological approach to predicting regional species distribution patterns in dryland ecosystems,” Advances in Water Resources, doi:10.1016/ j.advwatres.2009.12.003.
